description:
I used this app to re-size LVM volumes. It works like gparted where you make your changes and then click a checkmark to apply them. I received an error the first time I tried to resize the LVMs because I tried to shrink one LVM and grow another at the same time. When I ended up having to do was Shrink one volume - Hit checkmark - then grow the second volume and hit checkmark.

This app really came in handy. Being able to easily install and use it from the Fedora Live CD was great.
summary: Works well, really came in handy

description: The first time It took a lot of time analyzing my storage and I interrupted it. Since then, when I try to launch it, it says the app is already running.
I setup raid and it worked like a charm.
If you have Docker, don't even bother.
For a simple install it worked great and helped a newb like me.

Crashes due to duplicate group name on a different drive. While the crash is an LVM problem, the program should still allow the user to access other drives while preventing them from accessing the conflicting drive.
This is the only application I am aware of that can provide a nice overview of my quite complex storage configuration.
If you can't touch the main partition, nor the boot partition, what's the use of it? Going back to Windows to do the trick with known freeware, but it's a bit sad :(

Resizing and modifying of LVMs are not possible, just grayed out. Of course the volumes are dismounted.

Short: Useless.

The app is great and works well. If you can't manage a partition, it's mounted and in use. This app is very similar to gparted, but it can manage LVM also. The interface also works with my system theme and looks great. It doesn't do a great job of handling window resize events though. One other suggestion is to come up with a better name, I'll have to hunt in the menu for this one because I'll never remember the name off the top of my head. Otherwise, this will be my new goto for partition management.
summary: Great partition manager with a bad name

description: Default "Disks" is good, but it doesn't have tooling around LVMs. Blivet nails it!
Doesn't show % used of non-mounted partitions, which is important.
Pensaba que se podian manipular los lvm, esa es su supuesta ventaja, y con este programa no puedo manipular ninguno ( /, /home)
